snippet: New research may soothe the anxieties of parents worried that their children could lose state-financed services because of proposed changes to the official diagnosis of autism.
abstract: New report, posted online by The American Journal of Psychiatry, concludes that the proposed changes to the official diagnosis of autism will only exclude 10 percent of children currently on the spectrum from state-financed services, not the estimated 45 percent originally feared.
lead_paragraph: New research may soothe the anxieties of parents worried that their children could lose state-financed services because of proposed changes to the official diagnosis of autism.

headline.main: Report Sees Less Impact in New Autism Definition
headline.print_headline: Report Raises Questions On New Autism Definition
